answers.answer: It will eventually go away after going thru some color changes.  May take a while.You did the right thing with the pressure and the ice.  You are not likely to die from that small amount of bleeding, so you wouldn't have needed 911.  Picture in your mind a whole cup full of blood-even that amount is only 240cc's, and people who donate blood give almost twice that amount!  Saturating a couple of tissues probably contains at most 20cc of blood.Are you taking aspirin or any kind of blood thinner?  That may have contributed to it.  But what you did was just right--hold firm pressure (without letting up to peek and see if it stopped) for AT LEAST 5 minutes.  If that doesn't stop it, hold firm pressure for 10 more minutes.I'm sorry you had that problem!

Tony,I had a very similar experience a few years ago ... except that when I took out my cannula the bubble was sort of a geiser!  I felt like a blood "old faithful" squirtin' out waay to much blood.  The thing about blood is that even a little looks like A LOT when it's outside our bodies.What we had done to cause all that was simply to break a capillary while removing the cannula.  In my mind's eye, I imagine that the cannula was right next to a capillary the whole time it was in me, but the process of removing it put just the right (or wrong!) pressure against it to spring a leak.The pressure & ice were exactly right and soon your body will reabsorb the "color."That gusher experience has, thankfully, only happened once to me.  I have had a handful of bruises that didn't result in any surface bleeding.  Inevitably, if I see one of those, I really DO need to change the infusion site because soon the blood will find its way UP the cannula (my basal rate is pretty low, so I may be more susceptible to such "backflow").Anyway ... hope the scare is a fading memory soon.

Dear Tony,While I have a son with type one and don't have alot of knowledge about pumps, I do have rheumitoid arthritis.  I give myself two injections with fairly long needles twice a week and have hit wrong a couple of times. You took care of it as I have been advised.  What I would like to explain, is in regards to the bruising. It will go away, at least with my experience. It is just blood that spreads under the skin.  If you have further concerns, please speak to your doctor about it.Please don't let this get you down. Try to look at the big picture and try and stay positive. I think a positive outlook to any disease (no matter how hard) is the way to go.Best of luck,dm

Thank you everyone.  Sorry to bring this topic up in case anyone out there was considering a pump.  I don't want to scare anyone.The afternoon before I had a really nasty headache (it was snowing and sleeting - bad weather) so I checked my Glucose and it was in the 90s (normal for me) so I took 2 Advils.When I removed the cannula I didn't pull on it or anything, just gently removed the tape and lifted it out and checked to see if was straight like I always do.  The site was okay for a second and I was going to put a Q-Tip of peroxide on it and then the blood literally came up and streamed down my stomach.  It looked like a scene out of ER.  Except it was me ....I thought I had all of this under control.  I was feeling better about myself and was almost to the point of accepting Diabetes and moving on. Sigh ....I'm nervous about removing my next one now.  In a week I have to rotate back to that side.  :^(I read where, to reduce the bruising, to put a warm compress on the bruise location for like 20 minutes twice a day.  It's supposed to circulate the blood in the area to flush it out of the skin where it seeped under.  Dunno if that works or not, but I'm trying it.  Otherwise, I put neosporin on the area and try not to look at it.You know - it seems whenever I feel like I'm getting used to all of this and start to accept my new life and what I have to do .... something like this happens and kicks me to the ground.  :^(  Why can't bad things just leave me alone for awhile ....
Tony- you did the right thing. WE have had this happen to our daughter. THe bruise will go away. You probably have blood under the skin . I would not worry about the bruise. It happens to all of us.

This exact thing happened to me when I first got my insulin pump. I actually had it happen 3 times within the first 6 months and each time it totally freaked me out. I called the 24 hour phone number on the back on my pump (mine is a Minimed 508) and they told me to try changing to a shorter cannula. The old one was 9mm but now I use the micros (6mm).  I switched to the smaller cannula maybe 18 months ago and have not had any "gushers" since.  I'm an average to thin person who exercises alot and they said that I probably should have been using the micros from the start.  Hope this helps!

We had a gusher experience one time right after tae kwon do.  We thought that perhaps the pulling of the tubing during the exercise might have caused the bleeding to occur.  My son didn't normally disconnect for tae kwon do because it doesn't tend to make him go low, but since then he has been. Now that I know other people have had the same problem, I wonder if it was just a coincidence.

same thing just happened to my 9 yr old..diabetes is a mean disease and it can get you down at times. please do not get discouraged by this scare! after all you have been through already, just look at this as another part of this experience and move on passed it. my 9 yr old shows me how strong diabetics are everytime he faces something like this and he gives me the strength to shake stuff like this off and get back to living. I will never say diabetes is easy..or things could be worse. I will say that I am lucky this disease is not going to take my son from me as long as we take great care of him and his needs. I wish you the best and will pray for a cure for all of you!

question: This morning I really had a scare.  Everything was going fine for an infusion set change.  New site went in without issue.The old site on the other side of my abdomen however - when I went to pull out the QuickSet - it came out fine.Then a big bubble of blood appeared out the cannula spot and it bled and bled and bled.  Never seen so much blood.  I grabbed a wad of tissues and applied direct pressure twice.  It soaked them and then finally stopped.  Tried to get ice on it to stop it from seeping under the skin but was too late.I was so scared it wouldn't stop and was ready to call 911 I was so scared.But it stopped after a minute - but left a dark circle around where the cannula had been and a tan bruise the size of a thumbnail around it.  A real big pump bump.  Not one that neosporin or peroxide is going to take care of.Anyone have any remedies to make the bruising and dark circle go away.  Best I can tell is that I may have hit a tiny capulary or something.There was so much blood .....I thought I had all this down.  It doesn't hurt now and isn't bleeding - but it looks horrible.  And it WOULD have to happen the day my endo's office is closed.I hate this.  I really hate this.  The bruising will go away right?  I'm not going to get a scar from that dark circle?  This really has me shook up.
title: Infusion Set Removal - Lots of blood, large bruising - help please anyone???
